content.description: Start a few feet in to the Girdle Traverse at a mid-sized tree on the ledge. There is a hard to see crack that begins halfway up. The crack itself faces SE. Climb face to a ledge/alcove and then follow the crack to the summit.
content.protection: Small to medium cams. Belay at the tree. Rappel from the bollard down the Standard Route to the saddle.
content.location: Left of center when looking at Haystack form the saddle. Refer to photo.

content.description: Scramble up into the rockhouse. Exit the left edge of the rockhouse on a short, but good face. No pro.
content.protection: Nothing. you'll see a couple old bolt hole, but nothing you can use.
content.location: Left edge of the rockhouse on the NE corner of the rock.

content.description: This is the most obvious line from the saddle which passes through the hueco with a short crack above it. Climb into the hueco from the left and exit it right or left protecting out of the crack.
content.location: Center of the main face. Rappel the route from the bollard or downclimb the Girdle Traverse.

climbs.name: Girdle Traverse
climbs.fa: Lee Fischer, Tom Seibert, Ellen Seibert - 1970

content.description: Nice heady scramble with serious risk involved. This is the easiest technical route to the summit of Haystack, but not the safest. From the saddle traverse the ledge left around the rock to the SW corner (very exposed and very high). HEad up the slabby face to the summit. Alternately, continue around the rock, completing the girdle with a top rope.
content.location: Scramble down from the ridge to a saddle between the main ridge and Haystack proper. This route traverses the rock slightly higher in elevation than the saddle. You can reverse the route if you top out, or rappel from the bollard.

climbs.name: Dirty Rastafarian Scoundrels
climbs.fa: Martin Hackworth, Mike Susko, Todd McDonald, Keith Phelps, 1989

content.description: Begins with a tricky traverse. Then the route ascends an increasingly exposed face up ledges and well featured slabs.
content.protection: Small to medium cams and tri-cams. Make sure you bring plenty of shoulder slings. There is also one pin.
content.location: This route begins a few yards downhill to the right as you face the pinnacle (north east side). Jump up onto an exposed ledge that gives you access to the NW face at mid-height. Traverse the rails to a ledge and angle up and right over some bigger ledges protecting where you can. Summit on the NW corner.

content.description:
This route has traditionally been described as separate from Haystack Rock, and while it is not on the pinnacle, the approach and return are the same so it makes sense to include it with Haystack.

Climb the long, mostly 4th class chimney in one or two pitches to the top of a block that is separated, by the chimney, from the main wall. Rappel back to the ledge against the main wall and head back to the saddle at Haystack.
content.protection: A big piece for the start and some smaller pieces for the upper part.
content.location: To reach the start, scramble down the gully past Dirty Rastafarian Scoundrels until you reach the base of the cliff. Head right (left if you faced the cliff) until you find a deep, recessed chimney at the right edge of a tall, expansive face. Climb up through a tight bulge, then exit left or continue up the right chimney past a ledge to the top of a block on the right. Rappel from a small tree to the left.
